subject: RE: [junit] Testing an interface with JUnit
msgSnippet: If this seems familar - I originally stole the idea from somewhere online...cant remember where, anyone know? I can remember it being a good resource for OO
messageBody:
If this seems familar - I originally stole the idea from somewhere
online...cant remember where, anyone know? I can remember it being a good
resource for OO techniques..

> -----Original Message-----
> From: Heath, Joseph [mailto:HeathJ@...]
> Sent: 15 October 2001 10:06
> To: 'junit@yahoogroups.com'
> Subject: RE: [junit] Testing an interface with JUnit
>
>
> You can use JUnit to help enforce the interface contract:
> eg
> A stack interface has push,pop - as well as defining these
> methods you also
> might want to define the behaviour
> eg
> an object pushed onto the stack is then retrieved by the pop method..
>
> Ive done this using an abstract test case (see code below):
>
> An implimentation of the Stack interface must then extend
> this test case,
> overwriting the setUp() to instantiate the Stack objects with the
> implementation type..
>
> This test case then becomes usable by all implmenetors of the
> interface..
>
>
>
> --
> Remember there is more to the interface than just the method
> signatures,
> there can also be some definition of behaviour, unit tests
> can help with
> this..
> --
> After an argument the other night in a bar with a friend I
> had to conceeed
> that documentation can also perform this role..;-)
>
>
> public abstract class TestStack extends TestCase {
>
> public TestStack(String name) {
> super(name);
> }
>
> //the following must be created by subclasses
> protected Stack fullStack; //a stack with items in
> protected Stack emptyStack; //an empty stack
>
>
> public void testPushAndPop() {
> //last in - first out
> fullStack.push("first");
> fullStack.push("middle");
> fullStack.push("last");
>
> Object out;
>
> out = fullStack.pop();
> assertEquals(out, "last");
> out = fullStack.pop();
> assertEquals(out, "middle");
> out = fullStack.pop();
> assertEquals(out, "first");
> }
>
> public void testPop() {
> //throws exception when empty
> try {
> emptyStack.pop();
> fail("Should raise NoSuchElementException");
> }
> catch (NoSuchElementException nsee) {
> }
>
>
> }
>
>
> /**
> * Tests the isEmpty function work as expected
> */
> public void testIsEmpty() {
> //basics
> assertTrue(emptyStack.isEmpty());
> assertTrue(!fullStack.isEmpty());
>
> //empty stack->push->not empty
> emptyStack.push("String");
> assertTrue(!emptyStack.isEmpty());
>
> //stack with one item->pop->is empty
> emptyStack.pop();
> assertTrue(emptyStack.isEmpty());
>
> }
> }
>
> > -----Original Message-----
> > From: Steve Freeman [mailto:steve@...]
> > Sent: 15 October 2001 09:55
> > To: junit@yahoogroups.com
> > Subject: Re: [junit] Testing an interface with JUnit
> >
> >
> > If you mean a java interface, then you don't test those. You
> > test an _implementation_ of an interface.
> >
> > A mock object, easymock or otherwise, is a way of testing the
> > _clients_ of an interface by substituting an alternative
> > implementation. There are interesting trade-offs for the
> > various techniques for implementing mock objects.
> >
> > Steve
> >
> > ----- Original Message -----
> > From: FrankSun
> > To: junit@yahoogroups.com
> > Sent: Monday, October 15, 2001 9:45 AM
> > Subject: Re: [junit] Testing an interface with JUnit
> >
> >
> > I think the easymock is the best way for testing Interface.
> > ----- Original Message -----
> > From: Eric Riou du Cosquer
> > To: junit@yahoogroups.com
> > Sent: Monday, October 15, 2001 4:13 PM
> > Subject: [junit] Testing an interface with JUnit
> >
> >
> > What is the best way to test an interface with JUnit?
> > How to use a factory for an interface in JUnit?
> >
> > Thanks for your help!
> >
> > Eric
> >
